node.label: The product factory uses the context to find the corresponding configuration. This is used to fetch the triples by calling the appropriate client(s). If more than one client is addressed, the results is combined and possibly filtered. The result is a canonical LD serialization (currently: XML/RDF and XML/SPARQL-RESULT-SET). This is transformed to the relevant serialization
GUI should probably be separated from the production factory, because specific GUI concerns are addressed. This might include a specific GUI configuration!

Environment (prod/dev) Docroot (add a foldername to the URI because of a proxy) Staticroot (location of static data, defaults to docroot or /) Version (version number of the LDT) Timestamp (build timestamp of the LDT) Sparql (public sparql endpoint yes/no) Configuration-endpoint (sparql endpoint for fetching the LDT configuration) Local-endpoint (default sparql endpoint for fetching data) Title (browser title for a particular stage, defaults to "Linked Data Theatre") Querycache (whether to cache the configuration, yes/none) Cache (wether to cache to response, yes/none)

URL (the original URL) Request-hash (an MD5 hash of the request) Language (the first language as presented in the accept-language header) User (when authentication has been performed) User-role (user role after authentication as specified) Format (requested mime-type, as part of extension, format URL-parameter or accept-header) Domain (the URL domain, to find the corresponding site) Subdomain (first part after the URL domain, to find a possible stage) Parameters (key/value, except the subject, format, representation and date parameters) Attributes (key/value)

Representation-graph (the graph that contains the configuration) Query (the part of the URL that identifies a query) Subject (the dereferenced URI, or the value of the subject URL-parameter) Docsubject (the actual URL or the value of the subject URL-parameter) Upload-file (path to uploaded file, and request method (PUT/POST))
GUI representation might differ from machine readable formats, but should contain the same information
